title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 14 july [1869?]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 14 July [1869?]
text: 14 July 1870Jul 14 dear Waltwell we have lived so far through the summer as you say i think last sundaySunday was the hottest day we have had this summer at any rate i felt the heat more than any time yet i thought if i had much to doodo i couldentcouldn't have done it as it was eddEdd went to church and George was away i had as much as i could doodo to get something for myself i thought of you i thought probably you was out somewhere where it was cooler than here it is as cool here as any place that is so far down town its being open in front makes it better it is comfortable to day i feel pretty well am thankfullthankful i am as well as i am) got your walterWalter dear with its contents all safe) hellenHelen Price was here yesterday she and her mother i expect over here the last of next week to make a vesitvisit i hope the weather wontwon't be so hot but i will try to make some preperationpreparation before they come hellenHelen says when you come home she is coming over to tea one day and then you can go home with her and stay all night mrsMrs. price has wrote to you hellenHelen says and she sshe's wondering all the time why you dontdon't write to her thinks waltWalt might send her a few lines) i beleivebelieve they think emmilyEmily will be married this fall they are a good family i think ellenHelen says the magic ruffle business is much better managed they have charged some of the persons to much better advantage so that mrsMrs. price will get in august about 500 dollar will get about that every six months) i expect georgeGeorge home next saturdaySaturday i think probably he will stay as kingsleyKingsley wishes him to inspect the new main that is to be laid from east new york) i had a letter from mattyMatty since i wrote to you they seem to be all getting along very well wants some of you to come out there she says the works will be done and none of you will come to see it she said she was going to write to you that hattieHattie was much pleased with her letter and picture shows it to all the folks mattyMatty says hattyHattie is up to her shoulders i am sorry she grows up so tall she is only 9 years old love to all and yourself waltWalt dear Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 14 July [1869?]
